TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit DefaultWorkflowSchedulerService extends System.Workflow.Runtime.Hosting.WorkflowSchedulerService

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Obsolete("The System.Workflow.* types are deprecated. Instead, please use the new types from System.Activities.*")

Docs.summary: Creates and manages the threads that run workflow instances on the workflow runtime engine.

remarks.format:
## Remarks
> [!NOTE] > [!INCLUDE[DeprecatedContent](~/includes/deprecatedcontent-md.md)]
<xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.Hosting.DefaultWorkflowSchedulerService> is used by the workflow runtime engine by default. It includes default support for having multiple workflow instances queued in the runtime thread pool. If you want to control the thread that is responsible for executing the workflow, use <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.Hosting.ManualWorkflowSchedulerService>.

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(class System.Collections.Specialized.NameValueCollection parameters) cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This constructor is invoked when the workflow runtime engine loads services from an application configuration file. The only valid parameter is `maxSimultaneousWorkflows`, which can specify the number of workflows that can be run at the same time.
Setting `maxSimultaneousWorkflows` to a high value might cause the .NET thread pool to starve. This could cause time-outs when a persistence service tries to complete a persistence transaction because <xref:System.Transactions.Transaction> objects also use the .NET thread pool.
If not specified in a constructor or configuration file, the default value for `maxSimultaneousWorkflows` is 5 for a single-processor machine, and (int)(5 * Environment.ProcessorCount * .8) for a multiple-processor machine. Note that (int)(5 * Environment.ProcessorCount * .8) is not always the same as (int)(4 * Environment.ProcessorCount), because of the rules of integer arithmetic.

Docs.exception: contains a null reference ( in Visual Basic).

One of the key values in the collection contains a null reference ().

One of the key values in the collection does not match the default key for .

Docs.param: An integer that determines the maximum number of workflow instances that can be stored in the thread pool queue.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class by using the specified maximum number of workflow instances that the service can run simultaneously.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Setting `maxSimultaneousWorkflows` to a high value might cause the .NET thread pool to starve. This could cause time-outs when a persistence service tries to complete a persistence transaction because <xref:System.Transactions.Transaction> objects also use the .NET thread pool.
If not specified in a constructor or configuration file, the default value for `maxSimultaneousWorkflows` is 5 for a single-processor machine, and (int)(5 * Environment.ProcessorCount * .8) for a multiple-processor machine. Note that (int)(5 * Environment.ProcessorCount * .8) is not always the same as (int)(4 * Environment.ProcessorCount), because of the rules of integer arithmetic.

Docs.summary: Gets the maximum number of workflow instances that can be stored in the thread pool queue.
Docs.value: An integer that represents the maximum number of workflow instances that can be stored in the thread pool queue.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The default value for this method is 5 for a single-processor machine, and (int)(5 * Environment.ProcessorCount * .8) for a multiple-processor machine. Note that (int)(5 * Environment.ProcessorCount * .8) is not always the same as (int)(4 * Environment.ProcessorCount), because of the rules of integer arithmetic.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void OnStarted() cil managed

Docs.summary: Notifies the that a workflow instance has started to run.

remarks.format: ## Remarks <xref:System.Workflow.Runtime.Hosting.DefaultWorkflowSchedulerService.OnStarted%2A> creates a thread for the first work item in the list of items waiting to be included in the workflow instance thread pool.

Docs.summary: Adds a workflow instance to the pending work items queue.

Docs.summary: Adds a workflow instance to the pending work items queue using the specified workflow instance using the specified multicast delegate.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Threading.WaitCallback> constructor to create your delegate method to run in the new thread.
